cisc3120.asteroids

Class Polygon

  • java.lang.Object
    • cisc3120.asteroids.Polygon

  •  class Polygon
extends java.lang.Object
    Models a polygon in 2-D space. This is a bit different from the Polygon class Java provides—you should take a look at that class, too, as it may be useful when you actually want to draw your Polygon on the screen.

    A polygon is described by three components: its shape, its offset, and its rotation.

    The shape is defined by a sequence of points. Make sure that you list the points "in order" as you would draw it without lifting up your pencil. If the sequence of points doesn't form a polygon, various calculations (and drawing) simply won't work. When you give the shape, it's only the relative positions of the points that matters. In other words: {(0,1),(1,1),(1,0)} is the same shape as {(9,10),(10,10),(10,9)}.

    The offset describes where the polygon is located in space--it's the position of the top-left boundary of the polygon.

    Finally, the rotation describes the rotation of the polygon, in degrees. In Java geometry, 0 degrees corresponds to "east", and positive rotations go clockwise (so 90 degrees is "south").

    Usage: The idea is that a polygon is created with a particular shape which is never changed. Its offset and rotation, though, can be changed via the move() and rotate() methods. This class can be extended to create polygon-shaped game elements with additional characteristics and behaviors (like, say, asteroids and ships).

    Again, you may find that you want to add things to this class--make sure that those are things which all polygons in your name need to have.

    Author:
    Scott Dexter

    • Constructor Detail

      • Polygon

        public Polygon(Point[] inShape,
       Point inOffset,
       double inRotation)
        Creates internal representation of a polygon. The main work is storing this polygon's shape as a sequence of points located at the origin of the coordinate system.
        Parameters:
        inShape - array of Points that defines the polygon's shape
        inOffset - polygon's offset, as explained above
        inRotation - polygon's rotation, as explained above

      • Polygon

        public Polygon(Point[] inShape)
        A convenience constructor which takes a sequence of points and puts the polygon at the origin with rotation 0.
        Parameters:
        inShape - array of Points that defines this polygon's shape

    • Method Detail

      • rotate

        public void rotate(double degrees)
        Rotates the polygon.
        Parameters:
        degrees - Number of degrees by which to rotate this polygon clockwise.

      • move

        public void move(double x,
        double y)
        Moves the polygon by adjusting its current offset.
        Parameters:
        x - value by which to increment this polygon's x-offset
        y - value by which to increment this polygon's y-offset

      • paint

        public void paint(java.awt.Graphics brush)

      • getPoints

        public Point[] getPoints()
        Computes the actual location of this polygon in 2-D space by applying the current offset and rotation to the shape.

        Don't worry if you don't follow the math, though it's actually not that complex.

        Returns:
        array of Points describing the actual position of the polygon

      • contains

        public boolean contains(Point point)
        Determine whether this polygon contains a given Point. Again, don't worry about the math; if you're interested, it's the "ray-casting" algorithm.
        Parameters:
        point - the possibly-interior point to test
        Returns:
        true if point

      • findCenter

        private Point findCenter()
        Helper method for computing the centroid of this polygon. This relies on computing the area of the polygon.
        Returns:
        the Point at the center of this polygon
        See Also:
        findArea()

      • findArea

        private double findArea()
        Helper method for computing the area of this polygon.
        Returns:
        The area of this polygon.
